title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique legal relationship between the United States and Indian tribes, acknowledging tribes' authority to provide governmental programs, develop economies, and maintain infrastructure on reservation lands. Federal laws and regulations affirm tribes as governments with the authority to tax, issue bonds, and receive tax exemptions. Indian tribes face historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure and job creation due to statutory restrictions on governance. Tax parity with tribal governments is consistent with Federal treaties recognizing tribal sovereignty. Some provisions in the Internal Revenue Code result in unfair tax treatment for tribal citizens. The Revenue Code of 1986 has provisions that lead to unfair tax treatment for tribal citizens and unequal enforcement authority for tribal agencies. Congress has the authority to regulate commerce with Indian tribes to further tribal self-governance and affirm the government-to-government relationship with tribes. SEC. 3. TREATMENT OF INDIAN TRIBES AS STATES WITH RESPECT TO BOND ISSUANCE. The amendment to section 7871 of the Internal Revenue Code treats Indian tribal governments as states for certain purposes, specifically regarding tax-exempt bonds. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to establish a national bond volume cap for bonds issued by Indian tribal governments based on population estimates and minimum state ceiling amounts. The amendment to section 7871 of the Internal Revenue Code removes the Essential Governmental Function Requirements for Indian tribal governments seeking national bond volume cap allocations. The effective date for these changes varies depending on the subsection, with subsection (a) applying to obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of the Act, and subsection (b) applying to transactions and obligations issued in calendar years after the Act's enactment. The SEC. 4 addresses the treatment of pension and employee benefit plans maintained by tribal governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes. The term "governmental plan" now includes plans established by Indian tribal governments. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of qualified public safety employee and governmental plan. This allows for the establishment of plans by Indian tribal governments for their employees. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of qualified public safety employee and governmental plan. Plans established and maintained by Indian tribal governments or their subdivisions before a certain date are grandfathered and treated as if established by an eligible employer. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 has been amended to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or their subdivisions as governmental plans. This includes entities wholly owned or controlled by Indian tribal governments under Federal, State, or tribal law. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 has been amended to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or their subdivisions as governmental plans. This encompasses entities wholly owned or controlled by Indian tribal governments under Federal, State, or tribal law. Amendments also include domestic relations orders and conforming amendments to the Act. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 has been amended to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or their subdivisions as governmental plans. This encompasses entities wholly owned or controlled by Indian tribal governments under Federal, State, or tribal law. The amendments made by this section apply to years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Tribal foundations and charities treated like charities funded and controlled by governmental funders and sponsors. The amendment expands the definition of "governmental unit" to include Indian tribal governments and related entities for tax purposes. Additionally, certain supporting organizations are now deemed to include Indian tribal governments and related entities. The definition of "governmental unit" for tax purposes now includes Indian tribal governments and related entities. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. Improving tribal child support enforcement agencies by providing equal access to federal parent locator service and tax refund offsets. Access to Federal Parent Locator Service and improving the collection of past-due child support from federal tax refunds for Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for grants under specific sections of the Social Security Act. The section applies to Indian tribes or tribal organizations eligible for grants under specific sections of the Social Security Act. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code includes Indian tribes and tribal organizations in references to States for tax refund purposes. SEC. 7 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include Indian tribal governments in determining special needs for the adoption credit. The amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
